text: They also do no iniquity: they walk in his ways.
text_kjv: They also do no iniquity: they walk in his ways.
text_niv: They do nothing wrong;they walk in his ways.
text_esv: who also do no wrong, but walk in his ways!
text_nlt: They do not compromise with evil,and they walk only in his paths.

text_nasb: They also do no unrighteousness; They walk in His ways.
context: Psalm 119 is an acrostic poem, the longest psalm, and perhaps the longest chapter in the Bible, dedicated to extolling the virtues and power of God's law (Torah). It is generally attributed to David, though some scholars propose other authors from the post-exilic period. During the time this Psalm was likely written (either the Davidic monarchy or post-exile), the understanding and application of the Law were central to the Jewish identity. The Law wasn't just a set of rules; it was viewed as God's gracious gift, a guide for living a righteous and blessed life. 'Iniquity' held a strong connotation of deliberate rebellion against God's established order, a conscious choice to stray from His covenant. 'His ways' referred not just to physical paths but to the whole manner of living as prescribed by God's commandments, statutes, and judgments. The repeated emphasis throughout the Psalm underscores the life-giving and protective nature of obedience. The Psalm was likely used both for personal reflection and corporate worship, serving as a reminder of the importance of living in accordance with God's revealed will. The emphasis is on the comprehensive and pervasive influence of God's word on every aspect of life, highlighting its role in shaping character and conduct. The historical context shows a people deeply invested in understanding and adhering to God's instructions, seeing it as the key to national well-being and individual righteousness. Understanding this background helps to appreciate the intense devotion expressed by the psalmist toward God's law.
meaning: Psalm 119:3, "They also do no iniquity: they walk in his ways," speaks of a life characterized by both the absence of wrongdoing and the active pursuit of righteousness. The phrase 'do no iniquity' isn't simply about avoiding sin; it indicates a conscious effort to refrain from any act that deviates from God's standard. It points to a heart that is attuned to God's will and actively seeks to avoid transgression. This is further emphasized by the declaration that 'they walk in his ways.' This isn't a passive state; it's an active journey, a deliberate commitment to follow the path that God has laid out. 'His ways' represent the totality of God's commandments, principles, and character. To walk in them is to align one's thoughts, words, and actions with God's revealed will. The verse highlights a synergistic relationship between avoiding evil and actively pursuing good. One cannot truly walk in God's ways without diligently striving to abstain from iniquity. Conversely, simply avoiding sin without actively seeking to live righteously leaves a void that can easily be filled with other forms of ungodliness. The verse reveals that true righteousness is not merely the absence of wrong but the active presence of God's character reflected in our lives. It presents a holistic picture of a life dedicated to pleasing God, both in what it avoids and what it embraces. This verse underscores the importance of intentionality in pursuing a Godly life; it's not something that happens passively but requires deliberate effort and unwavering commitment.
application: Psalm 119:3 provides a powerful guide for modern living. In a world saturated with temptations and moral compromises, the call to 'do no iniquity' is more relevant than ever. This means actively identifying and avoiding situations, environments, and influences that could lead to sin. It requires a proactive approach, not simply reacting to temptations as they arise, but anticipating and preparing for them. Practically, this could involve setting boundaries in relationships, limiting exposure to certain media, and choosing to spend time with people who encourage righteousness. The second part of the verse, 'they walk in his ways,' speaks to the active pursuit of God's will. This isn't just about avoiding sin, but about intentionally seeking to live in accordance with God's principles in every area of life. This involves studying the Bible, praying for guidance, and seeking wisdom from trusted spiritual mentors. It also means actively seeking opportunities to serve others and to use our gifts and talents to further God's kingdom. We can apply this by regularly evaluating our actions and attitudes in light of God's word, asking ourselves whether our choices reflect His character and values. Are we treating others with kindness and compassion? Are we honest in our dealings? Are we using our resources responsibly? The verse calls for a lifestyle of continuous growth and refinement, constantly striving to become more like Christ. Living out Psalm 119:3 in a practical way transforms our lives into a living testimony of God's grace and power, influencing those around us and pointing them to the truth of the Gospel. It involves making daily choices that reflect our commitment to both avoiding evil and actively pursuing righteousness.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you acknowledging my need for your guidance and strength. Forgive me for the times I have fallen short of your perfect standard, for the iniquity I have allowed into my life. Help me to turn away from all that displeases you, and grant me the wisdom to discern your will in every situation. I desire to walk in your ways, to follow your path, and to live a life that honors you. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, empowering me to resist temptation and to actively pursue righteousness. Teach me to love what you love and to hate what you hate. Guide my steps, direct my thoughts, and mold my heart to be more like yours. Help me to be a living example of your love and grace in the world. I thank you for your forgiveness, your mercy, and your unwavering love. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Walking in His ways is evidenced by obedience to God's Word, a growing love for others, and a desire to please Him in all things. Regular self-examination through prayer and scripture will help reveal areas needing growth.
faqs.question: Q1: How can I know if I'm truly 'walking in His ways'?

faqs.answer: 'Iniquity' refers to any act or thought that violates God's moral law. In a modern context, this includes dishonesty, greed, lust, hatred, and any form of injustice or oppression, big or small.
faqs.question: Q2: What does 'iniquity' specifically refer to in modern context?

faqs.answer: Grace is the foundation of our ability to turn from iniquity. We strive not out of obligation, but out of gratitude for God's unearned favor. Grace empowers us to obey and forgives us when we fail.
faqs.question: Q3: How does grace fit into striving to 'do no iniquity'?

faqs.answer: Practical steps include daily prayer and scripture reading, seeking fellowship with other believers, actively serving others, and making choices aligned with biblical principles in all aspects of life.
faqs.question: Q4: What practical steps can I take to 'walk in His ways' daily?

faqs.answer: While we strive for holiness, complete freedom from sin is not attainable in this life. However, through God's grace and the power of the Holy Spirit, we can grow in righteousness and resist temptation more effectively.
faqs.question: Q5: Is it possible to completely avoid all iniquity in this life?
